name: Manila
content:
Manila is alive. You feel the energy in the streets, the density of people, the culture of smiles. Despite the negative, the hospitable filipino is present in almost everyone. Remember this and you will have a different perspective on this otherwise dark city.

The Poblacion area in Makati, once the red light district is a lively area where innovative ideas sprout. To stay in the middle of it go to https://zhostel.com. There's a variety of drinking and dining options around the hostel and across the big avenue. We like https://www.facebook.com/AlamatFilipinoPub for its craft beer, cocktails and tasty "Polutan" (filipino for food to go with drinks).

La Fuerza Compound in Chino Roces Ave hosts galleries, cocktail bars and clubs. Go to https://www.facebook.com/finderskeepersMNL first and then either https://www.facebook.com/blackmarketmnl for younger crowds, hiphop and RnB or https://www.facebook.com/2020bar for a Berlin inspired space with electronic music. Or visit https://www.facebook.com/obarphilippines after 1am. This 12 year old institution has amazing drag shows, they make their own costumes and every night is different. For after-hours go to https://www.facebook.com/TIMEinManila, back in Poblacion, usually opens till 8am.

There are two established museums in Makati, http://www.ayalamuseum.org and https://yuchengcomuseum.org. The http://www.silverlensgalleries.com shows contemporary filipino artists. If you are around on the weekend don’t miss the markets in https://www.facebook.com/SalcedoCommunityMarket and https://www.facebook.com/legazpisundaymarket - farmer's market with food stalls and crafts. For cheap wholesale go to https://www.greenhills.com.ph. The https://www.philippineartisantrade.com in Salcedo curated a group of Filipino startups worth checking out.

If well Manila isn't famous for its street food as other asian cities, it hosts some great local and world restaurants. Our picks are https://www.facebook.com/warungindoo, unpretentious Indonesian place for lunch. https://www.facebook.com/handsomecome offers modern malay fusion and http://www.peoplespalacethai.com serves refined thai food.

For filipino comfort food visit a https://www.buddys.com.ph branch or get delivery. We also love the flavors and decoration of https://www.facebook.com/cafe.juanita.ph in Passig and for an especial fine dining experience you can visit https://www.facebook.com/toyoeatery. If you are craving for sweets and good coffee visit a https://www.facebook.com/TildeCafe.

Old Manila and Intramuros for spanish colonial flair - take a https://www.bambike.com/ecotours tour to explore the walled city. visit Rizal Park for http://www.nationalmuseum.gov.ph.

In Quiapo there’s a famous https://www.facebook.com/savessbasilica. The foundation in charge of restoration holds 3 monthly talks on saturday mornings, visit their Facebook for schedules. San Sebastian Street and Quiapo market are further attractions close by.

Rush hour traffic in the city can cause hours on delays. Keep this in mind when moving around specially to catch flights. To commute between Manila and Makati you can use the MRT/LRT systems - tip, if you dont take a bag, you can avoid long security check queues.

The Pasig river ferry is a great alternative but service can be unreliable, always research online for newest schedules. It is worth visiting the Guadaloupe stop to check, because if its not working the MRT station is 5min walk from there. Grab and Uber are great for moving around Makati and to/from the airport. Also langka app (motorcycles) for solo travellers.

name: Puerto Princesa
content:
For slow paced explorers is worth to check out some of the other attractions in Palawan. We start in the provincial capital where you can stay two nights and one full day. Start your day around 8-9 at the Publicmarket to see all the fresh produce coming in. This might be the most biodiverse fish market in the world.

After this you can visit one of the specialized shops around town, like http://asiano.ph for tribal crafts specially wood carvings. Puerto is also famous for its https://www.facebook.com/camiciapearls. Dont miss https://www.facebook.com/titoernies for lunch. Next door there's a weaving centre and a boutique where they sell their signature pineapple textiles and designs. After all this you might want to go back to your hotel for a nap. Use your afternoon to realax in a spa or more retail therapy and then for sunset visit the butterfly garden.

The http://www.palawenobrewery.com is a great spot for craft beers and then dine in http://www.kaluirestaurant.com for seafood or https://www.facebook.com/Kinabuchs-Palawan-128793830486080 to try local delicacies like wood worms or alligator sissig.There are several full day experiences to arrange out of Puerto. Dolphin and whaleshark (seasonal) interactions or a visit to the Underground, River https://www.facebook.com/dolphinandwhales can organize these experiences.

The highway between Puerto and El Nido has a few surprises. San Vicente has a 14km long beach, the longest in The Philippines, Port Barton looks and feels like El Nido 10 years a go and in Roxas you can visit a small vietnamese restaurant that has tasty Bahn- Mi and Pho - reminder of a wave of vietnamese war refugees. These are low key destinations so you can just visit, explore and ask around for places to stay and eat.

links.text: Palawan Butterfly Garden and Tribal Village

name: El Nido
content:
After or before your trip you might want to explore El Nido Bay, during the Tao Trip we usually avoid the busy tourist attractions like the lagoons, the "Secret" beach, etc… our expertise are the remote islands and our boats are too big to access these super crowded places. The several operators in town all offer pretty much the same package. Some of the hostels will offer you a more boozy experience, while the high end ressorts will have fancier snacks. Its up to you and your budget.

A way to explore the mainland is by renting a motor bike. North of El Nido you will find waterfall and villages. Your first stop is the Nagkalit-kalit falls and then Kalitang Beach. Arterwards head to Baratoan, San Fernando and Sibaltan. This last has some small ressorts, you can get a massage, food and visit the local museum and community shop. Finish the loop back in El Nido and explore Pasadeña area and Lio Beach.

El Nido eats: Bulalo Plaza for filipino slow food, Altrove serves good fire oven pizza in 2 outlets - Pop’s District in Corong Corong and in town, Tamboks is close to the airport and serves signature dishes from a local chef, spanish run Republica has the perfect sunset spot, cocktails and good Paella.

To sleep we prefer Corong Corong, check Palauyu, Telasfora and Coral Cove. Or just research online for promotions and other traveller’s suggestions as new places open all the time.

name: Coron
content:
In Coron we suggest you come and stay with us in our newly opened Camp Ngey! Ngey! there are promotions as Expedition add-on and it is the perfect place to prepare for your expedition or decompress afterwards.

Coron is a great spot for wreck diving. Arrange a trip with one of the several operators. For a place to stay in town we recommend you check Divine Castle or Palanca Guest House.

Most places to visit around Coron Town are only accessible by boat. Island Hopping trips are easy to be arranged in town, the office can help you arrange a private boat for a personalized experience or you can join one of the scheduled tours from the multiple operators.

Go up mount Tapyas to the Coron sign for sunset and after dark get a tricycle to the Makinit Hot Springs, the tricycle should wait for you outside. You can also rent a bike and explore villages and waterfalls, there are no beaches on the mainland since all the Busuanga coast line is covered with mangroves. The boys hanging out at the office will give you the best tips as they are always about on their time off.

There is also Altroves in Coron, but usually with long waiting times. La Sirenetta or Winnie's are good for sea food lunch since they get sea breeze and not so hot at noon. At night time visit the grill houses, Kawayanan on the road to the airport and Carl's bbq on the road up to Mt. Tapyas.
